quotes.topic_title: Product-led sales requires new internal collaboration
quotes.text: The most important thing in product-led sales is that there is a different configuration internally of collaboration that needs to occur.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets the core mental model that product-led sales requires rethinking internal collaboration, not just tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Product-led sales requires new internal collaboration
quotes.text: In the product-led sales, product acquires and activates a customer and product creates pipeline for sales, so relationship is not that there's a go-to-market org with marketing and sales and product just kind of throws features across the fence for them to sell.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines the operating model shift: product becomes responsible for acquisition/activation and pipeline creation rather than only shipping features.

quotes.topic_title: Product-led sales requires new internal collaboration
quotes.text: The collaboration here is between product and sales, but that means the product has to take on accountability over pipeline.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on org design: align product and sales with shared ownership of pipeline outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Product-led sales requires new internal collaboration
quotes.text: The worst thing that you can do is to say, "I'm going to do product-led growth," or, "I'm going to do product-led sales and I'm going to do it in marketing." Recipe for disaster.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that running PLG/PLS solely from marketing is structurally flawed and likely to fail.

quotes.topic_title: Product-led sales requires new internal collaboration
quotes.text: You'll be failure mode within six months because product has to take accountability over selling of the product itself.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides a concrete failure horizon and reinforces that product must own the in-product selling motion.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In this conversation, we go incredibly deep into the emerging space of product-led sales.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Flags product-led sales as an emerging discipline worth investing time in understanding and applying.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Elena explains what exactly is product-led sales, how it fits together with product-led growth and sales-led growth, who and when you should consider investing product-led sales, how product-led sales changes your approach to sales and marketing, what sorts of data, tooling, and people you need in place to do it well, and what common pitfalls you need to avoid.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical implementation checklist covering definition, fit, timing, org changes, required capabilities, and pitfalls.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Elena has worked at or advised companies like Miro, Amplitude, SurveyMonkey, MongoDB, Netlify, and a dozen others.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes breadth of real-world B2B experience across multiple leading product companies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Linear is different. It's incredibly fast, beautifully designed, and it comes with powerful workflows that streamline your entire product development process from issue tracking all the way to managing product roadmaps.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Linear read)
quotes.context: Highlights an end-to-end workflow approach to reduce friction across the full product development lifecycle.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What users love about Linear are the powerful keyboard shortcuts, efficient GitHub integrations, cycles that actually create progress and built-in project updates that keep everyone in sync.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Linear read)
quotes.context: Lists specific operational levers (shortcuts, integrations, cycles, updates) that teams can adopt to improve execution and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Braintrust charges a flat rate of only 10%, unlike agency fees of up to 70%, so you can make your budget go four times further.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Braintrust read)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete cost benchmark and a simple ROI heuristic for evaluating hiring channels.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Take it from DoorDash, Airbnb, Plaid, and hundreds of other high-growth startups that have shaved their hiring process from months to weeks at less than a quarter of the cost by hiring through Braintrust's network of 20,000 high-quality vetted candidates ready to work.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Braintrust read)
quotes.context: Offers recognizable proof points plus time/cost deltas that can inform expectations for hiring process improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're looking to fill in gaps, upscale your staff, or build a team for that dream project that finally got funded, contact Braintrust and you'll matched with three candidates in just 48 hours.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Braintrust read)
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operational promise (three candidates in 48 hours) that teams can use as a speed benchmark for staffing.

quotes.topic_title: Elena’s current work and advising availability
quotes.text: between interim roles I always take about six to eight months of break because interim rolls are very intense because there's so many deliverables that are loaded in in the first year that you're working at the company
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical operating cadence for interim leaders: plan deliberate recovery time because interim scopes compress a year’s worth of deliverables into a short window.

quotes.topic_title: Elena’s current work and advising availability
quotes.text: I'm just advising. I have incredible companies that I started advising such as Veed.io and Sanity and Clockwise, and I'm building up my next level of frameworks that I'm going to dive into potentially a new interim position to prototype.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Shows a repeatable approach to career leverage: advise to learn across companies while developing frameworks, then validate them by prototyping in an interim role.

quotes.topic_title: Elena’s current work and advising availability
quotes.text: I'll never take down an opportunity to have a great conversation and to learn about the business and to see how I can be helpful, but I'm not proactively sourcing clients, but that doesn't mean that I don't have availability to schedule something in the future.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A boundary-setting model for advising: stay open to high-signal conversations without running an active client acquisition motion.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-led sales vs product-led growth
quotes.text: Product led growth is all about product's ability to self-serve activate, self-serve engage, and convert that usage to a monetization opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines PLG as a self-serve funnel from activation through engagement to monetization, giving practitioners a clear operating model.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-led sales vs product-led growth
quotes.text: Extraction of the value can be direct where you're actually capturing revenue from them, or it can be indirect where they're participating in your growth model via virality or user-generated content and bring additional business through the doors.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Introduces a direct vs. indirect value-capture lens to broaden how teams measure PLG outcomes beyond revenue alone.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-led sales vs product-led growth
quotes.text: Self-serve monetization has a cap of about $10,000.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides a concrete threshold practitioners can use to decide when self-serve monetization likely needs a sales assist.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product-led sales vs product-led growth
quotes.text: Product-led sales converts the usage that you've generated via self-serve into a sales opportunity and it attaches a salesperson to close a much larger contract, which can be 15, 20, a hundred thousand dollars in order to bring an enterprise-level solution to a company that has already been using it in a self-serve manner.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clarifies PLS as a conversion mechanism from self-serve adoption to sales-led expansion, with concrete contract-size examples.

quotes.topic_title: Individual-to-enterprise escalator and enterprise value
quotes.text: Product-led sales assumes that there's a migration from an individual use case that you acquired an end user with and an escalation into an enterprise-level solution that solves enterprise-level problems.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines the core PLS mental model: designing an “escalator” from end-user value to enterprise outcomes worth selling.

quotes.topic_title: Individual-to-enterprise escalator and enterprise value
quotes.text: Amplitude, individual, what is individual wanted with Amplitude? I need data at my fingertips to make better decisions for my product, so I'm going to put an Amplitude SDK into my product and it gives me behavioral data to help me build my pillar better. What is the company-level solution? Well, it's more self-serve ability of the data. It's democratization of data. It's enhanced insights in the more data-driven culture. That's what company's solving for. Individual is not solving for data-driven culture. Individual is just solving for data insights for them. Company's solving for data-driven culture.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Concrete example of mapping individual JTBD to enterprise value, useful for crafting packaging, messaging, and sales motions.

quotes.topic_title: Individual-to-enterprise escalator and enterprise value
quotes.text: products fundamentally do a really bad job at communicating enterprise-level value prop. They're very good at showing you as a user what you can do. They've very terrible at showing what organization actually can benefit out of the solution.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive diagnosis of why sales is needed in PLG: the product UI excels at user value but fails at org-level ROI storytelling.

quotes.topic_title: Individual-to-enterprise escalator and enterprise value
quotes.text: Sales can tell that story. Sales can bridge that gap, and then you can increase the perceived value in order to bridge the gap to that $15,000, 20, hundred-thousand dollar contract.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on sales’ role: translate usage into enterprise narrative to justify higher contract values.

quotes.topic_title: Individual-to-enterprise escalator and enterprise value
quotes.text: self-serve monetization is very much an individual use case versus product-led sales is turning that individual use case and self-serve usage into a sales pipeline with enterprise-level value.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clear distinction practitioners can use to decide when to stay self-serve vs. invest in PLS and pipeline creation.

quotes.topic_title: When sales is needed: motivation, ability, permission
quotes.text: Yeah, so to understand how sales should be applied in the situation, you need to understand end user's motivation, ability, and permission.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic framework for deciding when and how to involve sales in a product-led motion.

quotes.topic_title: When sales is needed: motivation, ability, permission
quotes.text: However, that's not always the case. A lot of times the end users miss permission of solving enterprise-level problems. There's lots of stakeholders, there's a committee that has to make a decision. It impacts departments outside of their purview and maybe they even lack ability to do it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Explains the core enterprise adoption blockers (permission, stakeholders, cross-department impact, ability) that necessitate sales involvement.

quotes.topic_title: When sales is needed: motivation, ability, permission
quotes.text: In my Amplitude example, yeah, I can drop an SDK in my product area, but how do I convince entire product to adopt Amplitude and put an SDK on every single interaction across the entire app?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete example of the gap between individual usage and enterprise-wide rollout where sales can help drive internal alignment.

quotes.topic_title: When sales is needed: motivation, ability, permission
quotes.text: Product-led sales has to bridge those friction points by either attracting the right decision-makers to the process so they can find an enterprise buyer out there. They can understand who's the champion and what their capabilities and what their permission levels are. They can create a committee for the decision.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable description of what product-led sales actually does: stakeholder mapping, champion qualification, and decision orchestration.

quotes.topic_title: When sales is needed: motivation, ability, permission
quotes.text: There is... They almost slap a bandaid on the problem of people not be able to and not wanting to necessarily resolve the problem on their own.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable, slightly contrarian framing of sales as a pragmatic fix for organizational friction and stalled self-serve adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Miro and Figma enterprise problem statements
quotes.text: Nobody's going to pay a hundred thousand dollars to solve a team-level small problem that is solving. What is the enterprise-level problem? It's increased innovation, it's increased productivity across the entire team because now we have this new outlet in which we can collaborate.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for reframing product value from team-level use cases to enterprise-level outcomes that justify large contracts.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Miro and Figma enterprise problem statements
quotes.text: Now, can Miro very clearly show increase in productivity across the organization by using the product? No. Can sales tell the story? Yes. Miro takes you from an individual user to a team step, and then sales bridges the gap to an enterprise.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Explains the product-led sales “bridge” role: product drives adoption to team, sales translates that into enterprise ROI narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Miro and Figma enterprise problem statements
quotes.text: What is it on the enterprise level? Well, on enterprise level, our designs are just better fit the business needs. They have faster turnaround time and our product is performing better.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Concrete example of elevating a designer workflow benefit into enterprise business outcomes (speed, fit, performance).

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Miro and Figma enterprise problem statements
quotes.text: That's an enterprise-level value prop and, again, we're, I think, in the product development space gotten a little bit lazy of actually showcasing that enterprise value in product. We rely on excellence of sales team to tell that story.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian critique that challenges teams to embed enterprise value proof into the product instead of outsourcing it to sales.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Miro and Figma enterprise problem statements
quotes.text: I do hope that changes, by the way, in the future, that we put more pressure on the products to take it all the way up the escalator so we don't have to be a hundred percent dependent on the sales team going and showcasing that story. The product can really empower that escalator from the starting point till the end on its own.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable direction for product teams: design the product to carry users from initial use case to enterprise justification without relying entirely on sales.

quotes.topic_title: Why hand-raisers plateau and pipeline must be created
quotes.text: you should never hire any salespeople until you feel that pool because if nobody's asking to purchase, then you cannot just hire an SDR and make a purchase happen.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive hiring trigger: wait for real inbound enterprise pull (“hand-raisers”) before scaling sales headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Why hand-raisers plateau and pipeline must be created
quotes.text: That organic demand very quickly dries up if you rely on hand-raisers of your champions.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Warns that early PLS success from inbound champions is a temporary phase and will plateau without a new pipeline engine.

quotes.topic_title: Why hand-raisers plateau and pipeline must be created
quotes.text: 90% of product-led sales is converting the usage into an opportunity by finding a buyer outside, by finding the decision-maker outside.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable framework for where the real work in PLS happens: turning product signals into pipeline by reaching decision-makers beyond users.

quotes.topic_title: Why hand-raisers plateau and pipeline must be created
quotes.text: Just it doesn't last very long just because end user fundamentally does not equal enterprise buyer and that organic demand ends up plateauing very shortly because you cannot just make enterprise buyers happen from your users.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clarifies the core mismatch that causes hand-raiser-led growth to stall: users and enterprise buyers are different people with different incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Who should invest in product-led sales
quotes.text: To have product-led sales means you're going upmarket-
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A crisp mental model that frames PLS primarily as an upmarket strategy, not just a sales add-on.

quotes.topic_title: Who should invest in product-led sales
quotes.text: That means you going for contract values that are probably over your sales floor, so the minimum that the sales is willing to engage and close, which is traditionally around $15,000.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Gives a concrete threshold (“sales floor”) practitioners can use to decide when PLS becomes relevant.

quotes.topic_title: Who should invest in product-led sales
quotes.text: If you are not ready to go upmarket, I would say keep it easy on the product-led sales because sales means quotas.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable warning that adopting PLS changes operating constraints (quotas) and effectively forces an upmarket motion.

quotes.topic_title: Who should invest in product-led sales
quotes.text: Those persons are not interested in talking to sales in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that adding sales can hurt fit for prosumer/startup segments that prefer self-serve.

quotes.topic_title: Who should invest in product-led sales
quotes.text: it's really need to be conscious about what that will do to your go-to-market motion because it definitely skews it and pulls it up.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights the practical GTM consequence: PLS reshapes the whole motion by pulling the business upmarket.

quotes.topic_title: Two paths to PLS: from PLG upmarket or SLG downmarket
quotes.text: Right, so there's two ways to get to product-led sales.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Introduces a simple two-path framework for adopting product-led sales depending on whether you start PLG or SLG.

quotes.topic_title: Two paths to PLS: from PLG upmarket or SLG downmarket
quotes.text: The reason to go into product-led sales is either your existing top-down motion is not working because customers need to see value before they sign the contract.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Explains a key trigger for adding PLS: enterprise buyers increasingly require proof of value pre-purchase.

quotes.topic_title: Two paths to PLS: from PLG upmarket or SLG downmarket
quotes.text: Or you're going downmarket and your fixed cost of sale that you have from the traditional sales motion does not scale.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights the unit-economics reason to adopt PLS when moving downmarket: sales costs stay constant while ACVs drop.

quotes.topic_title: Two paths to PLS: from PLG upmarket or SLG downmarket
quotes.text: You can approach it from both ways. Adding PLS on top of product-led growth or adding PLS on top of existing sales-led growth. For PLG, you're going upmarket by adding PLS. For SLG or sales-led growth, by adding PLS you're going downmarket.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides a memorable directional model: PLS is the bridge that enables PLG to go upmarket and SLG to go downmarket.

quotes.topic_title: Product must own monetization and pipeline creation
quotes.text: I think every sales-led company should be putting pressure on product to assist with the sales process.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete directive for SLG orgs: start by making product directly support the sales motion, even before full PLG.

quotes.topic_title: Product must own monetization and pipeline creation
quotes.text: The biggest difference here that starts to come in, and that is so apparent in every single company, is that in B2B, unfortunately, we've let go of the products having accountability over monetization model.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian diagnosis that reframes monetization as a product responsibility that B2B teams have ceded to GTM.

quotes.topic_title: Product must own monetization and pipeline creation
quotes.text: We've gotten into the spiral of product just builds a product and it throws it over the fence to marketing and sales to sell.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the common anti-pattern that blocks product-led monetization and pipeline creation.

quotes.topic_title: Product must own monetization and pipeline creation
quotes.text: Revenue stream one will be your self-serve revenue, and if there's self-serve revenue, that means product is selling literally itself, so yes, there has to be somebody in product that has self-serve revenue target.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical ownership model: assign explicit self-serve revenue targets within product when the product sells itself.

quotes.topic_title: Product must own monetization and pipeline creation
quotes.text: It's what volume, velocity, feature breadth, or behavioral signals that account is throwing that says, "Hey, right now is the time to engage with sales."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A usable framework for defining product-qualified accounts via measurable engagement thresholds that trigger sales outreach.

quotes.topic_title: PQA vs PQL vs MQL and three lead paths
quotes.text: Product qualification is very much product metrics. It's the volume of use, it's the velocity change. For example, yesterday I've been adding one user per day and then today I've added 15 users to account. That's a velocity change that you need to pay attention to.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines PQA in terms of concrete, usage-based signals (including a specific velocity-change example) that teams can operationalize for sales triggers.

quotes.topic_title: PQA vs PQL vs MQL and three lead paths
quotes.text: However, the more you move up the market, the more end user is many steps separated from the buyer, so you might have very healthy usage and you might have a PQA that is off the charts, but you don't have a PQL in it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights a common enterprise trap: strong product usage doesn’t automatically mean you have an actual buyer to sell to.

quotes.topic_title: PQA vs PQL vs MQL and three lead paths
quotes.text: If you just stick your sales against that account, you're going to have a very terrible situation and very terrible user journey where users are like, "Why is sales talking to me? I have no decision-making power in my organization. I love the product, but please leave me alone."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Warns that mis-targeting sales outreach at non-buying users can damage the user experience and waste sales effort.

quotes.topic_title: PQA vs PQL vs MQL and three lead paths
quotes.text: Those three channels are super important to identify. They all have very different conversion rates. They all have different playbooks of how you close them and, honestly, they require often different sales team to go after them because it's a very different sales enablement.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Introduces a three-path lead attribution model and the operational implication that each path needs distinct playbooks (and sometimes different sales teams).

quotes.topic_title: Avoid jamming PLS into top-down sales motions
quotes.text: the piece here that a lot of companies miss, unfortunately, is that they jam product-led sales into a traditional top-down sales playbook.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights the core failure mode in PLS: applying enterprise sales mechanics to early, product-led user journeys.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid jamming PLS into top-down sales motions
quotes.text: In product-led sales, a new user that signs up, they know we're close to enterprise-level consideration. They're just trying to complete an individual job to be done. They're not solving a problem for their company.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clarifies the mental model shift: initial PLG intent is individual JTBD, not company-level buying intent.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid jamming PLS into top-down sales motions
quotes.text: If you can imagine, it is like a very large funnel. You start with just users looking for problem solve. Then, you transition to awareness, consideration, and intent channels for team level problem. Then, you escalate for awareness, consideration, and intent channels for enterprise-level problem.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides a staged funnel framework for progressing from individual usage to team and then enterprise intent.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid jamming PLS into top-down sales motions
quotes.text: If you go after individual user that just signs up for the account and you reach out to them 10 minutes later after sign-up asking, "What's your budget and are you ready to buy?", it's a complete mismatch of where they are in their consideration journey.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Gives a concrete anti-pattern practitioners can avoid: premature sales outreach that breaks the user’s journey.

quotes.topic_title: Avoid jamming PLS into top-down sales motions
quotes.text: You cannot consider a new product sign-up an MQL in the traditional sense. They're just not there yet.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A crisp rule-of-thumb for aligning qualification and outreach to actual user intent and stage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Rows is different. It combines a modern spreadsheet editor, data integrations with APIs and your business tools, and a slick sharing experience that turns any spreadsheet into a beautiful interactive website that you'll be proud to share.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear product framework: editor + integrations + sharing to make spreadsheets operational and publishable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're writing a report on a growth experiment, you can use Rows to do your analysis on data straight from Bitquery or Snowflake.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of pulling source-of-truth data directly into analysis workflows for growth reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Or if you're working with sales, you can natively plug Stripe, Salesforce, or HubSpot directly into Rows.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable integration pattern for sales ops: connect billing + CRM data into a single spreadsheet surface.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When you're done, you can share your work as a beautiful spreadsheet that's easy to read and embed charts, tables, and calculators into Notion, Confluence, or anywhere on the web.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical distribution method: turn analysis into reusable, embedded artifacts across internal docs and the web.

quotes.topic_title: Building PLS: data approach and PQA modeling
quotes.text: There's different levels of scale on how you should be attacking this problem. First of all, it starts with just top-down intuition. What are the signals that you're seeing around the accounts that are highly correlative to sales being very excited-
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Introduces a staged approach to building product-led sales, starting with sales intuition before heavier analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Building PLS: data approach and PQA modeling
quotes.text: The one thing is not to do is just to start sending every single user to sales because that's the fastest way for sales to say, "This product channel is garbage and I don't ever want to see a lead from it again."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Warns that flooding sales with low-quality product leads can permanently damage trust in the channel.

quotes.topic_title: Building PLS: data approach and PQA modeling
quotes.text: That should be your first PQA model. It should be very simple. It should just be if you can run a linear regression against some of the top coefficient that you notice so you know which has the biggest weight to predictability and you go with that.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Gives a practical starting point for PQA modeling: simple regression to identify the strongest predictive signals.

quotes.topic_title: Building PLS: data approach and PQA modeling
quotes.text: The main piece here is to involve sales very early on so you're partnering with them. You are not just dumping it on them and that you have a very strong feedback cycles from sales or whether what you've identified is correct or not correct because PQA definitions should not be static. They're constantly evolving.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Emphasizes tight sales feedback loops and continuous iteration as core operating principles for PQA definitions.

quotes.topic_title: Building PLS: data approach and PQA modeling
quotes.text: I don't know if I would start there right from the beginning unless you actually understand the data because buying a platform will not bridge the gap for you understanding what actually matters in your data.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Challenges the instinct to buy tooling early, arguing understanding the data must come before automation and platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Common PQA signals: users, volume, velocity, behaviors
quotes.text: One of the biggest PQAs is number of users in the company using your product. By the way, the magic number is usually seven.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Gives a concrete user-count threshold teams can use as a simple PQA trigger for sales engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Common PQA signals: users, volume, velocity, behaviors
quotes.text: "Hey, there's enough value here distributed across multiple people inside the company that there might be an enterprise conversation to be had."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable framing for why multi-user adoption signals readiness for an enterprise sales motion.

quotes.topic_title: Common PQA signals: users, volume, velocity, behaviors
quotes.text: The last one I would say is velocity. Velocity is the trickiest one just because we don't have a very easy way to measure velocity in our transactional data, but it's actually one of the most powerful one that triggers the right timing for the involvement because the change in velocity either number of users being added or events being sent or storage that is being utilized is usually a fantastic predictor.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Introduces velocity change as a high-signal timing mechanism for when to involve sales, beyond static usage levels.

quotes.topic_title: Common PQA signals: users, volume, velocity, behaviors
quotes.text: At Miro, we had a very strong behavioral signal that if there is an admin switch in the account, some sort of evaluation is happening.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights a specific, trackable behavioral event (admin change) as an enterprise evaluation indicator.

quotes.topic_title: Common PQA signals: users, volume, velocity, behaviors
quotes.text: The other one that is fascinating is your terms of use pages, your privacy and policy. Nobody cares about it unless they're considering enterprise deal. If you see anybody from account land on your terms of use pages, reach out to that person.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive but actionable signal: legal-page visits can identify buyers and prompt timely outreach.

quotes.topic_title: Over-outreach risks: channel saturation and user trust
quotes.text: You have only so many channels to communicate with a customer.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A scarcity framing that encourages teams to treat attention channels as limited assets to protect, not exhaust.

quotes.topic_title: Over-outreach risks: channel saturation and user trust
quotes.text: Stepping back and thinking when it's the right time to reach out. How can I grab their attention?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical prompt to shift outreach from volume-based to timing-and-attention-based decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Over-outreach risks: channel saturation and user trust
quotes.text: If you highly saturated the channel that is your primary for reaching out to the user, they're not going to react even if it's more of a right time for them to react.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that overusing your best channel reduces responsiveness precisely when it matters most.

quotes.topic_title: Over-outreach risks: channel saturation and user trust
quotes.text: Will it hurt you? I don't think you'll notice it right away, but over time I think people become blind to channel communication if it's not applicable to them because, "Fool me once, shame on you." Like, "Fine, you tricked me to opening this email." Fool me twice, it's shame on me and I'll be a lot more frugal of which emails I open or which notifications I react to.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how repeated irrelevant outreach trains users to ignore future messages across email and notifications.

quotes.topic_title: Over-outreach risks: channel saturation and user trust
quotes.text: I think that you have to put user journey first and you have to really think about the timing that it's right for user and PQA.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A guiding principle to prioritize the user journey and align outreach timing with readiness signals (PQA).
